reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s use of cross-view judgments of “ongoing moral catastrophe” (Section 2.1) as evidence that large, non-obvious value-loss is common, and so eutopia is fragile. If that evidential move were undermined, it would weaken one strand of motivation for fragility, but much of the paper’s case (later examples of specific failure modes, multiplicative/product framing, and the technical bounded/unbounded ‘fussiness’ analysis) could largely stand, so centrality is moderate (~0.3). The objection itself is plausible—there is a risk of treating mere moral disagreement, including ontologically/idiosyncratically grounded doctrines, as evidence of likely catastrophic value loss—yet it’s not fully developed: it doesn’t show Forethought is actually relying on “any dissenting doctrine” rather than a subset of reasonable views, nor does it quantify how much the fragility conclusion depends on including those views. So strength is modest (~0.35). It is fairly relevant to Forethought’s agenda because it bears on their Tier-3-style concerns about moral uncertainty/pluralism and how disagreement should inform expectations about flourishing/trajectory (and connects to their later discussion of intertheoretic comparisons), hence ~0.6 relevance. Overall impact is limited (roughly 0.3×0.35≈0.1) but upgraded somewhat for being a constructive methodological pressure point, yielding ~0.22.
title: "The critique conflates moral disagreement with catastrophe"
